title: Back cable protector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
edit 06.01.18:

  • Uploaded v3 of the first design, made it longer because the bed cable sometimes went over its end towards the extruder and back over it during some large prints. It wouldnt tug on it but would push it bit by bit. So this is better. No "logo" anymore either.
    Added a gcode i did in ideamaker with the model flipped over so it has minimal supports.

This is not essential but more of a piece of mind addon-mod for CR10.

I noticed that even with Strain Relief Upgrade (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2186203) which is essential, the cable in the back still tends to scrape over the corner of the printer main structure. So if you also dont like seeing that, or getting the occasional tug, this little mod will prevent that and give you piece of mind.

There are two versions of the model, one more robust and the other with just the cover. Choose whichever you want they both fit and work fine. If the bigger CRs have the same structure dimensions then this will fit for them too.

Installation is very simple, you just put the protector onto the back left corner, make sure that the front nub under the curve sits nicely into the groove in the gantry of the printer and thats it. The cable just slides over it so there is no great force and it wont move or fall off. The bed can move without problems.

But If you want you can additionally secure and tighten it with a zip tie through the two small holes at the back, on both sides.

Have to give thanks and props to my co-testing-pilot @goofdad for checking the models and printing them in various orientations to make sure they turn alright. My prints had some problems with the curves but thats some kind of issue on my side. Models were checked in Meshmixer and Ideamaker and have no faults or mistakes.

Printer:

CR_10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.16

Infill:

30

Notes:

I made them in PLA, which is fine. Any other filament will be good too.
15 to 20% infill should be ok. The gcode provided is set to 30 infill and 0.16 layer height with 0.4 nozzle.

title: CCG geared card box (updated)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I saw a box for CCG cards with a gearing system to raise the cards up. I thought it was quite nifty but at the same time, overly complex, requiring multiple metal pins. This is my own take on the concept.

Huge update - 05/12/17:

I have redesigned this significantly, with a much simpler construction method, two sizes for 60 and 100 card decks, and an embossed version for Magic: The Gathering players.

The following instructions are for the redesigned version.
To assemble, print the pieces you want. You need a cart, base, lid and pivot plates for each box. The components should already be in the best printing orientation in the STL file. Check the pivot plates slide into the base along the groove in each corner. Then, place the cart in between the lids, and the pivot plates onto each lid. Then just slide the entire top section into the base. The pivot plates should slide into the grooves at the bottom, and friction should keep the whole system together. If they're a bit loose, then just use some glue on the pivot plates when inserting them.

The following information and instructions are for the original version.
First, a little bit on the pivot plate components. The original design included pivot holes in the base print. However, there was usually insufficient flex to slip the lids into place, resulting in breakages. The pivot plates were developed to allow flex so that the lids could be put into place, and at the same time mean that only a tiny bit of reprinting was required if the plates broke.

To construct, print all the components. Then fit the pivot plates into the base (see photo). They should fit fairly flush with the side walls, so that the gears on the lids can fit past them. Because they've been printed with layers running along the long axis they should be able to fit in place and flex to accept the pivot pins on the lids. If they don't, then you could also place the entire system (lids, pivot plates and card cart) into the base all at once.

If you want to modify this and include a logo on box, then you can simply emboss a logo into the front, so long as it doesn't extend out past the pivot plates. The plastic thickness is 2.4mm.

Note: I'm still running an older lid design on my box - which is why there's a discrepancy between the lid and base when closed in the photos. The uploaded design has lid and base with the same width.

Note 2: I'll update this in the future for different deck sizes. If you want any particular size let me know.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

yes

Notes:

Print the cart and base in the normal orientation.
Lids are in their correct orientation for printing - with their sides downwards.
Pivot plates should be printed with their flat side downwards.

You may need to trim the pivot plates somewhat to get them to sit flush. They're designed to be quite a tight fit.

I regularly design and print things that have to match and work with real world objects, so my designs run a fairly tight tolerance, and I've made sure my printer can meet that. Almost everything I design I have also successfully printed using a fairly standard Wanhao i3 plus.

Please contact me for a custom mount. This design can be easily modified for different tilt angles and attachment options.

print_settings.Notes:: ABS plastic to use solvent+insertion magnets application.

description.text:
Demo video:
https://youtu.be/dnjngOsvjrw

Child lock for furniture.
Can be attached via double sided foam tape or screws

In armed state the small magnet lifts main magnets as a spring and lifts the hook.
To disarm just enclose the magnet "key" at about 5cm and this overdrives the "spring" magnet.
To permanently disarm - just remove the spring magnet from the bottom of the lock.

What you need for one lock (BOM):

  • 1 inch of 3mm rod. I used a steel one.
  • two 6x3 mm magnets
  • one 4x2 mm magnet

You will also need some big magnet to act like a key.

When assembling assume the magnets polarity. Two 6mm has to be in one polarity and have to attract the key magnet. The smaller 4mm magnet has to push away 6mm magnets when all is assembled.

To attach magnets to plastic use any ABS solvent, apply some to the holes where magnets meant to be, then push magnets there and wait the solvent to vaporize (max 24h).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

0.2

20-30%

description.text:
I wanted a wall stand for my Nintendo Switch but could not found one that was small and discreet and allowed me to exit the cables to the left side of the Switch so I made my own.

This stand has cut-outs for the hinges on the back side, and has a 10mm gap between the wall stand and the docking station to allow space for both for the cables and for airflow for cooling.

If you have ferrites on your HDMI-cable you might not be able to fit the cable in the space behind the docking station and the wall, please consider that before printing the wall stand, or simply get another HDMI-cable.

The slots for the hinges are made to stop the Switch from being able to fall off the stand sideways.

The screw holes are made for counter-sunk screws like for example dry-wall screws.

I mounted this so the cables are hidden behind our tv, and I think it turned out pretty good since it´s discreet and almost looks "original"

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-50

Notes:

I printed this on a Prusa i3 Mk2s with PrimaValue black ABS at 100mm/s with Linear Advance set to K30 at 0.2mm layer hight and 50% infill to get it really strong, but I think you can use any filament and it will probably work down to 20% infill (print it and try to break it, if you can´t, then your Switch can´t :)

I printed it without supports and got tiny bridging problems around the cut-outs for the hinges but I made the cut-outs with margins to compensate for this, but you can print with supports if your printer or settings don´t manage bridging good.

Made in about 20 minutes in Fusion 360.

I started by printing a 10mm section at 5% infill to check the fit to the docking station before I printed the entire wall stand, I suggest you do the same since the fit depends on your calibration of your printer, and the shrinkage of your filament.

This is my 3D interpretation of Amanda's walker linkage system. I'm planing to do full scale model, but first I need a workable printed model. Scale is 1:1 to Amanda's Mathematica's units. Her thesis on this subject can be found here: http://www.amandaghassaei.com/mechanical_walking_machine.html This is first model and it is not (properly) walking yet. It's basically a proof of concept. I'm allready working on a second model, just arhiving that one here.

Printed on Ultimaker derivate: Troublemaker.   
For one leg you need 2x 75, 2x 56, 77 and 77koleno. Shaftgear has "integrated" 26 shaft, so you need that one too.   
Be aware of two types of legs avalible, choose those you can print.

title: Xbox One Kinect Tv-mount for LG Plasma

description.text:
This is a simple tv-mount for a Kinect camera for Xbox One.

It´s made to fit a LG 60PS8000 Plasma tv.

The two holes are for zip-ties if your tv is tilted at an angle so the Kinect can fall off.
The half-circle in the back of the mount was made because of a screw in the tv.

I was originally thought of as a prototype to see how what I could add to stop the mount from tipping forward, but it turnes out the cable to the camera is so heavy that there was no need for any further fixation of the mount, atleast not on our set up and with the angle our tv is tilted.

Design made using TinkerCad.
CCSS

Civil Engineering Project 1 - Bridge Building Problem Civil Engineering Project 1
Design Requirements:
As a Civil Engineer working for the State Department of Transportation, your team is tasked to design an appropriate type bridge to cross the river. OBJECTIVE:
  • Design a bridge that can carry its own weight and the weight of two semi-trucks and other traffic across the river (FIG 1 & 2)
  • Select from three different bridge types for your project. (See below)
  • Create a 2D draft of your project bridge on graph paper.
  • Use TinkerCad for you building materials.
  • Submit your file for printing.

Plan Project Sequence
Day 1 – Along with your partner, decide on the type of bridge your team will build.
Begin drafting/drawing your bridge to scale.
Keep within the boundaries: Length no longer that 10 inches
Width no wider than 6 inches
Height no higher than 8 inches
Keep a daily journal of your activities for the portfolio. Be sure to take screen shots or use the camera option on your laptop and save these pictures to your PowerPoint Presentation.
Day 2 – Begin working in TinkerCad, you may share the project with your partner via the share option.
Enter today’s work into the journal/ upload pictures.
Day 3 – Continue working on the bridge and remember to work on your PowerPoint Presentation.
Enter today’s work into the journal/ upload pictures.
Day 4 – Finalize Bridge build & submit for printing.
Enter today’s work into the journal/ upload pictures.
Day 5 – Present to the class. (See separate rubric) *--

AZ State Standards Link to Google Drive Docs
[https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1R1wPbqVfdgMJHbauWyW9fkWHnZmap-Lg?usp=sharing] You are welcome to use these docs/pics for ideas
I used BridgePoint Bridge Builder Software for the design models

author: kraft_pl

description.text:
Creatlity CR 10 Bed Insulator

Hey CR 10 owners. I have created this auto-retracting insulation layer for your printer.
WHY do you need it? .... Because if you want to print at high bed temperatures (closer to 100 C) then your CR 10 battles to get up there. This mod will get the temperature up in considerably less time and safely removes itself once the bed moves to the Zero position.

I designed it for a set of springs that I had lying around but I also included hooks so you can simply use elastics if you like.
You will need to cut a sheet of double walled card board to fit in order to complete the job. Bits snap onto the frame and board can be glue-gunned into board position as required.

GCode for PLA provided.
You will need 2 of everything and just one 'Hook'

title: Imperial Assault Terrain Tile Box with Lid

description.text: This is a box that holds the little terrain tiles and tile connectors from Imperial Assault. It's configured such that there is a place for many of the distinct types and room for the expansions. The tiles are oriented so that the ID number on the tile is at the top for easy searching.

comments.text: The box itself works great for the tiles (very cool design), but I cant seem to make the lid fit, it just falls off and doesn't push all they way back.. I had to rotate it 180 so it printed flat side down, but strangely enough it only fits into its grooves if i put it on the upside down. I've been using the fast setting (0.35 layer height) for my prusa i3. Are there different settings you'd recommend?
comments.author: mikebourgeault

comments.text:
it sounds like the overhang for the edge isn’t printing well for you on the prussia. you may just need to increase the size by 1% or use a slightly higher resolution so the slope is printed and catches on the slides. different materials shrink at different rates as well so your pla might be slightly more prone to losing dimensional accuracy than mine.
is take a close look at the model and your print and see if you can spot the specific differences and then pick the right counter measure for you printer / filament combo.
comments.author: mikebourgeault

comments.text:
Running off a lid now at a higher resolution and scaled up 1%, will let you know how it goes
.
comments.author: thetrebor

comments.text: Can’t wait to hear!
comments.author: mikebourgeault

comments.text: Printed at 0.10 layer height, and scaled up 1%, lid slides in better now, stays well enough to keep the pieces from falling out! Waaay better than the ziplock bags I was using!
comments.author: thetrebor

comments.text: glad it worked out and that it works for you!  sounds like your filament shrinks a little more than mine.  I'll post my rails system for IA as soon as i have the bugs worked out.

author: npo

description.text:
Hi, this is a work in progress project of a modular rolling robot platform.

The idea is to provide :

  • a standard modular chassis
  • a set of "heads" (brackets) for different front sensors
  • a few variations of the rear caster
  • various wheel designs
  • adapter plates for different electronics boards (PICAXE, Arduino, Raspberry Pi..)
  • space for batteries under the chassis
  • some kind of front gripper or arm
  • an hexapod kit

Versions

  • Standard size is 75mm wide by 130mm long

  • Narrow size is 56mm wide by 130mm long

  • v0_0 is a first release without any mounting holes for the electronics
  • v0_1 includes holes for Arduino Uno R3, Picaxe 28x2, 28x1 and 08 project boards.

BOM

  • a pair of "continuous rotation" mini servos. They can be bought as is or you can make the mod yourself See the attached PDF it contains a step-by-step procedure I've written ages ago
  • a standard SG90 micro servo for the head, a pair if you want to use the pan/tilt bracket
  • a 1.5 or 2mm pin for the rear caster
  • flex material il you want to print the tires, but rubber bands will do
  • an other good and extra cheap option for tires is to buy "10 Pcs 60mm x 3.5mm Mechanical Nitrile Rubber O Ring Oil Seal"
  • a Sharp GP2Y0A21YK0F IR sensor or an HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor
  • a bunch of M3 screws and nuts, as all the holes have a 3.2mm bore (as on the electronic boards except the 2mm for the Picaxe08)

Stay tuned !

Videos

  • V0_1 in an arena with a BoeBot : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xHTAqvC1kc8

description.text:
In our school, the equipment we use for rotational motion labs is over $200 for a single lab setup. The Moment of Inertia Spinner is designed to replace the expensive equipment with something that is much cheaper and easier for students to set up.

The entire lab setup for two students is less than $1, and the spinners are robust enough that they shouldn't break even if they are dropped.
NGSS

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/XEbUYx4T6yI&feature=em-upload_owner" ></iframe>
Moment of Inertia Spinner in action in the lab
The video above shows a typical lab setup of the Moment of Inertia Spinner.

Computing Moment of Inertia (45 minutes)
  • Record video of the falling mass using Hudl Technique, or any other Video Motion Analysis software.
  • Compute the angular acceleration of the stick, assuming a constant angular acceleration.
  • Compute the torque applied to the spindle, given the weight of the hanging mass and the radius of the spindle (0.016 meters).
  • Use the relationship between net torque, moment of inertia, and angular acceleration to compute the moment of inertia of the meterstick.
  • How does the computed moment of inertia of the meterstick compare to the theoretical moment of inertia of a meterstick (I = 1/12ML²)? Why are they different?

Requirements
  • this spinner, printed at 1:1 scale
  • 2 x standard 8 mm ID x 22 mm OD skateboard bearings
  • For Best Fit: 5/8" wooden dowel
  • For A Poor Fit: a pencil
  • a meterstick or similar object to mount to the spinner to provide a large moment of inertia
  • tape to attach the meter stick to the spinner
  • 1 meter of string
  • a small hanging mass (500 grams or less is preferable)
    • Assembly Instructions
  • Press fit one bearing into the top of the spinner.
  • Press fit a second bearing into the bottom of the spinner.
  • Insert wooden dowel or pencil through the spinner so that it penetrates both bearings.
  • Tape a meterstick or other object onto the flat "wings" of the spinner.
    • Using the Spinner Starting with a spinner that is assembled per the instructions above:
  • Tie a small mass (100 - 500 grams is preferable) to a 1 meter long string.
  • Wind the string around the spindle.
  • Clamp or hold the dowel onto the table such that the meter stick can spin freely.
  • Release the mass, recording the length of time it takes the mass to fall and the final rotational speed of the spinner.***
    • ***We have found that this works well if students use their mobile devices with an app such as Hudl's "Technique" for iOS so that they can get accurate frame-by-frame video. Specifications String Spindle Diameter - 32 mm
    Bearing Outside Diameter - 22 mm
    Bearing Inside Diameter - 8 mm
    Maximum Bearing Width - 10 mm

The Nue (鵺, 鵼, 恠鳥, or 奴延鳥) is a legendary Japanese yōkai or mononoke.It is described as having the face of a monkey, the legs of a tiger, the body of a tanuki (Japanese raccoon dog) and the front half of a snake for a tail. In other writings nothing is stated about its torso, so it is sometimes depicted to have the torso of a tiger. The Genpei Jōsuiki describes it as having the back of a tiger, the legs of a tanuki, the tail of a fox, the head of a cat, and the torso of a chicken.

title: Door Stop with internal foam spring

description.text:
One of my bathrooms has a cool feature where if you let the entry door swing all the way open, it activates the push to lock automatically, an unpleasant delay for the next person trying to use that room to say the least..

I wanted to stop the door from opening all the way, but with some cushion. I had some spare 15mm diameter insulation (bought at Home Depot) from another project (see picture) so I designed this in three pieces.

Assemble all pieces including foam before attaching..

1) Main block, can use command strips or hot glue on both sides
2) Piston, Install small end into the largest end of the main block, it has a built in stop to prevent it from falling out. Insert a cut piece of foam a bit longer than the hole
3) Cap, after installing foam, push cap on to lock foam in place

Stick or glue down and you're done. I printed mine on high speed, took about an hour. Works great, it does make a interesting little zippy sound, perhaps you might sand the piston, but the sound doesn't bother me.

author: xorshift99

title: Cyber Bunny - King of Tokyo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cyber Bunny from the first edition of King of Tokyo. Designed to replace the cardboard cutout that comes with the game. Some assembly required.

There are three options for printing:

  • SINGLE - The full model in a single file. This may be very tricky to print.
  • FULL (+COMMON) - The model sliced in to few pieces, easier to print, but must be assembled afterwards
  • FLAT (+COMMON) - These files are the easiest to print, as overhangs have been minimized, but there's a lot of assembly to do after printing.

If you print the FULL or the FLAT files, you'll need the COMMON files as well.

I printed my parts in ABS, and used ABS slurry to glue the parts together.

The fists are remixed from Tardis Transformer V2 by Ellindsey.

You can find the rest of the King of Tokyo monsters in this collection. There is also a blog post with more information about the models.

Assembly

The parts do need to be glued together. If you printed the FLAT parts, start by gluing the two halves of each part together first. Here I used plenty of ABS slurry to make sure any gap between the halves gets filled. Any excess slurry can be cut or filed off once the its is set.

Test fit each part before applying glue; The parts may need minor filing or sanding to fit.

comments.text: I just installed these. They work as intended. Maybe a bit of over kill vs the plain plugs with a little grease. One thing to watch out for, do not jam the bearing into the holder. That will make the center race drag on the back of the cup. The inside of the cup needs a little ridge to stop the bearing about .2 off the bottom. Your screws will need a little filing to get them to fit into the bearings, allowing a slip fit. the rods need to float in the z direction. And lastly, you will loose about 10 mm of height. If you switch the cap screws on the nut to countersunk you can get most of that back. But for me its not a big deal and a good trade off.

print_settings.Notes:: Each machine I had to run a test print first, then adjust the scaling percentage slightly to fit the PVC I had on hand.

description.text:
In my physics classroom we study projectile motion. Accurate projectile launchers with consistent results are very expensive ($200+). Because of this, I find that I have many students working with few launchers, diminishing the overall experience.

I have designed a launcher that I have been able to create for my classroom that costs less than $5 in materials. Aside from plastic, you will need a large spring ($0.80, I used menards part#88228, 13/16 x 3-1/4 compression spring), and a 5 inch section of 1" schedule 40 PVC pipe.

To launch, a paperclip is used to hold the plunger back. A swift yank will release the plunger, and your projectile should be launched. I used a 1/2" ball bearning, and I found that the projectile would travel around 11 feet, with an error of around 6 inches.

Some of the troubles I ran into, that I expect you will also find:
-PVC sizing is not as consistent as I initially thought. I had to adjust the scaling percentage slightly depending on the batch of PVC.
-PVC is not perfectly round. I found that every piece of PVC is slightly oval, creating asymmetric hot spots on the plunger.
-If you buy several springs, they will not create equal projectile launches.
-if you do not glue the printed parts to the PVC well enough, the launcher will disassemble itself during launch.
-securing the launcher in place is tricky, so I included a bracket that should effectively clamp the launcher to another surface with a nut and bolt.

Overall, my school was able to buy a cheap 3d printer (monoprice mp select mini) and print a dozen of these launchers for less than the cost of one traditional projectile launcher. The printed launchers do not shoot as well, but they are still quite accurate.

I have successfully printed this on the following machines:
Makerbot replicator (.3mm height with raft, no support)
Makerbot replicator + (.3mm height with raft, no support)
Monoprice MP select mini (.175mm height, no raft, no support)

Each machine I had to run a test print first, then adjust the scaling percentage slightly to fit the PVC I had on hand.

Post printing:
Make sure the Plunger (file 1) slides smoothly inside the PVC. Adjust with sandpaper if necessary, or reprint slightly resized.

Use any high strength super glue to permanently bond the launcher post to the plunger. This assembly should then be placed inside the PVC with the spring. Finally, use the glue to permanently bond the end caps onto the PVC.
I managed to break the stock end stops for the smooth rods on the Y-axis, So I model my own. They have the same dimensions as the stock ones to ensure they fit.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3Ji3eruUM5e

Youtube link: http://youtu.be/m3w0liy-QJE 3d printed planetary gear with gear bearings connecting the carrier to the gear planets. This allows (potentially) for reduced frictional losses in comparison to sleeve bearing. The design is a extension of Emmett Lalish's innovative gear bearing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451 and also uses his pin connectors V3 library http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33790. The gear ratio is written on the using HarlanDMii Write library http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193

Print the carrier and the planetary gear separately and assemble.  
The included gear.stl uses a 0.15mm tolerance which may or may not enough for your printer.  It can be adjusted in the openscad source file.  
Material: 1.75mm Blue and red PLA from Colorfabb

Slicer: Kisslicer
Number of loops: 2
Layer thickness: 0.2mm
Extrusion width: 0.5mm
Infill: 33%
Extrusion temperature: 195deg
Bed temperature: 50deg
Perimeter speed: 20mm/s
Solid infill: 30mm/s
Sparse infill: 50mm/s

comments.text: Glad you liked the design :-) I think you need a pretty well calibrated printer to print this design. I made a few paper weights before I succeeded. description.text: Replica of Will Graham from the TV series Hannibal in sitting position

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

hyper

A few months ago, my father noticed a problem with my Honda Odyssey. My front bumper was coming off on the right side.
As it turned out, the end of the bumper has broken off right where the bumper was attached to the frame. I probably caught the bumper on something backing up, but the piece was totally gone.
The duct-tape solution was ugly, so I designed a simple piece in OpenSCAD to glue to the end of the bumper. It took a couple of tries to get the measurements right. It has a large flat surface (to for a strong glue bond), a hole in the middle (to replace the screw hole that broke), and a little side piece to match the existing lines.

If you happen to have a 2000 Honda Odyssey and managed to break the same part of your car, you're in luck.
To design it, I took the measurements and designed a flat rectangle in OpenSCAD. I punched a hole in it for the screw, added the side wall for looks, and then cut an angle so the piece would fit in the limited space I had to work with.
Print it out, glue it on, let it set, screw the bumper back in place.

title: Flashlight body for LED/reflector drop-in module V2

description.text:
This is version 2.0 of another flashlight, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2581075

The problem with the previous one was that while it was easy to assemble, electrical connections were difficult to make internally and finnicky. When biking with the light, it would flicker due to vibrations of the bike.

The new version has internal structures to support a 1.6mm / 14 awg diameter solid copper wire, commonly found in household mains wiring. The connection method is much more sturdy. See pictures for the wire bending.

Non-printed Ingredients:
1 protected 18650 cell
1 LED flashlight "drop-in", 26.5mm version. You can buy them from aliexpress, the ultrafire.com site, dealsextreme, etc etc. You want the ones with a reflector and a driver board already built in.
1 clear plastic circle 26.5mm - you can cut this out of anything, i used a dremel on a demo lens (ask for these at your local optometrist or optical store, they just throw them out)
1 SPST, 11mm diameter round latching switch from junk giveaway flashlights
12cm of 1.6mm /14awg solid copper wire and the will to bend it

Recommended materials: PETG or more heat resistant. NOT PLA.

print_settings.Notes:: I print out of ABS with a .2 layer height. Additionally I use an alternating 50% and 30% fast honeycomb infill. (Simplify 3D) This is all to accomadate the higher printing temperatures. This carriage should also work very well with nylon but I haven't tried this yet.

description.text:
This is a revision of this thing:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2366151
I very much like the design and simplicity of this carriage but wanted a version that would handle the stock LM8UU bearings. This has been modified to do just that. It also has a few other modifications.
There are a few to increase the strength in places that are close to the bearing channels; I felt they were too weak with the larger cutouts. Additionally, i increased the belt channel length to accept a longer belt. I felt that it would help with assembly as inserting such a short length can be a bit difficult. The last mod was to increase some dimensions to accommodate a higher temperature enclosure. I found that the carriage was warping inside of a 40C box when working with some high temp filaments. The carriage bottom and backplate were both thickened to help with the warping.

title: VESA Single or Dual Monitor Stand Using 1/2" Metal Conduit

description.text:
This is a monitor stand set up with mounting holes for VESA 100x100. All holes are sized for M4 bolts and nuts. It can be set up for one or two monitors (or more, technically). I sized the main holes for 1/2" metal conduit (like this: https://www.homedepot.com/p/1-2-in-EMT-Conduit-101543/100400405).

I'm using this with a 21" and a 19" monitor. I have had it up for a few weeks with no issues. No guarantees on how strong it is for larger monitors, use at your own risk.

I had some issues with the wing nut/bolt holder pieces slipping when the bolt tightens, that's why I included a couple of different designs. The wingnut/bolt holder pieces are optional, you could use just bolts and tighten with a wrench.

I have included a plain mount and a 2nd with 5-degree angle. Even greater angle would probably be better for my setup, maybe 15 degrees.

The base uses 4 bolts (length depends on thickness of mounting surface) and 4 nuts. Per monitor, you'll need 8 bolts and 4 nuts. (All M4 metric bolts & nuts.)

description.text:
This is a multi purpose platform for the Prusa i3 MK2s which makes use of the cut-out polygon ontop of the z-axis, providing you with real estate to build or attach anything you want to it. It has several pre-drilled holes for M3 screws which are self-tightening, no nut needed plus four cut-outs for cablebinders. The MPP itself fits perfectly without any screws, binders or anything and is very stable when printed with 100% infill.

There are two versions of the MPP, one for the left and one for the right side (as seen from the front), labeled as such.

I have made a Tray for the MPP to hold some tools I need frequently and with a convenient space to place screws, it can be downloaded here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2647994

For the other side I've made a Paper Towel Holder because as you know we should clean the bed before every print ;) You can download it here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2656138

Or use it as a mount for your Rasbpi, a place for Marvin to be or any other thing you always wanted to attach to the printer :D

description.text:
Made for you lucky folk that have Quad Extrusion... [Or tri or dual extrusion folk can do it by making the tag the same colour as the stars or something?]

This took far longer than it should for such a simple looking thing, but hopefully it'll look really great when printed - so looking forward to seeing some of your makes!

Kind of a retro dieselpunk/raygun gothic robot, derivation of my "Metal Pig" model which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26399 He's much smaller than Metal Pig, but still fairly large depending on what scale games you play (assuming he'd be for that in the first place). The pics are him alongside some commonly used 15mm and 28mm scale models respectively. Not a lot of changes made to the original model other than the head and scaling, though there;s some minor design alterations. Sculpted in Tinkercad. https://tinkercad.com/things/ijoIF0MROa0-deco-dieselbot-multiverse25mm
I printed him at 230 on the extruder and 110 on the plate at a layer height of .10 and %10 infill. Worked out just great!

description.text:
EDIT Nov. 28th: I honored that htxt.africa wrote about this build in their blog: http://www.htxt.co.za/2017/11/22/fatpiboy-is-a-different-kind-of-raspberry-pi-emulator/

I've seen lots of great RetroPie portables on Thingiverse, but none of them quite matched what I had in mind. I wanted to have:

  • 5 inch display
  • Raspberry PI 3
  • a removable game controller
  • a 4500 mAh battery I had laying around from an old Nexus 7 tablet

So, I introduce to you the FatPiBoy. Please bear in mind that this is my first rather complex design. This is the part list:

  • Raspberry Pi 3
  • 4500 mAh Li-Ion of a Nexus 7
  • Adafruit 5.0" 40-pin 800x480 TFT display without touchscreen
  • Adafruit DPI TFT Kippah
  • Adafruit Mono 2.5W Class D Audio Amplifier
  • Mini Metal Speaker (also from Adafruit)
  • Adafruit PowerBoost 1000 Charger
  • 8bitdo Zero controller

The PI is stuck to the back of the display using the screen_mount part and double sided sticky tape. Most of the wiring and components are based on the PiGGRL 2.0. The case can be closed up using 3 M3x16 screws. Original GameBoy for scale :)

Known Issues:

  • No access to the USB ports (there is space next to the ports, so one could extend one of the ports to the case)
  • HDMI output is occupied by the TFT

Edits:

  • Nov 18: Added new version of front with a deeper and wider hole for the controller and a small notch to make sure the shoulder buttons don't hit the case.
  • Nov 18: Added a small test print, so you can check if the controller will fit the case (prints in 40 min in comparison to 8h for the whole front).

Yes, it can be printed without supports, the printer bridges the controller hole just fine!

comments.text: I printed 2 of these and I like the result. But there is a flaw in the design. The corner where the speaker is placed is missing and M3 screw attachment. The enclosure will give a small gap there because it's not fully closed in the corner. I guess there is space in that corner to fix this?

comments.text: Thanks for your feedback! Yes, one could see this as a flaw. I wanted to try if 3 screws were enough, and in my case it was, so I've never designed the fourth screw in. I'll revise the design shortly.

author: wachsihh

description.text:
https://gamedecor.com/dungeon-core.html

Please note to print the floors standing up. The surface detail is so much better when you doing it standing and you can print more at a time since it saves space.

Game Decor has partnered with a very talented 3D artist under the banner of “DungeonWorks” and is going to be launching a Kickstarter for a new line of high resolution 3D printer files for modular dungeons and accessories. There are currently 3 lines of models with a total of 7 uniquely themed dungeons containing over 400 models planned for release. The first line consists of locations of classic encounters, such as the gothic stone dungeon, the dank caverns, and the half timbered town, all of which is easily compatible among the majority of fantasy settings. The second line is inspired by iconic computer based dungeon crawling role playing games where legendary settings are yours to design. The third line is driven by a high fantasy setting with tales of epic proportions. Several more themes and expansions for each line are planned to be released afterwards.

A little info about the 3 lines

“Classic Encounters” includes all your generic, classic settings. Basic dungeon, taverns, caves, city streets.

“Vintage Vault” is about recreating those classic video games and even board games. Everything in the game is recreated here in tile form. Relive the adventures of old or create new ones.

“Lost Realms” are deluxe sets. They're created just like a D&D module. There is an adventure theme already set out for a DM to build upon. So, these sets are heavily themed for instant adventuring.
